coredata.dc:title: Efficient photoreduction strategy for uranium immobilization based on graphite carbon nitride/perovskite oxide heterojunction nanocomposites
coredata.dc:creator: Li, Shuyang
Yang, Xiaoyong
Cui, Zhenpeng
Xu, Yang
Niu, Zhiwei
Li, Ping
Pan, Duoqiang
Wu, Wangsuo
coredata.dc:description: The photoreduction conversion of soluble U(VI) to insoluble U(IV) is an economical strategy for the efficient removal of uranium from radioactive wastewater. A graphite carbon nitride and perovskite oxide heterojunction composite (g-C3N4/LaFeO3) is designed for the photocatalytic reduction of U(VI) under simulated sunlight conditions from aqueous solution, the reduction-immobilization mechanism is interpreted with the aid of spectroscopic evidence. The proposed heterojunction structure exhibits efficient removal ability (460 mg/g) over a wide range of U(VI) concentrations due to the suppressed recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and the prolonged lifetimes of the photogenerated carriers. The catalytic efficiency is maintained at a high level after five cycles of reuse. The electrons on LaFeO3 transferred to valence band of g-C3N4, U(VI) is reduced by the electrons and ·O2 − on the surface of g-C3N4. The g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterojunction provides a promising strategy for the feasible recovery of U(VI) resources with inexhaustible solar energy.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Uranium removal
Photoreduction
Carbon nitride
Perovskite oxide

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Characterization of catalysts. (a) XRD patterns of the as-synthesized catalysts; TEM images of (b) g-C3N4, (c) LaFeO3 and (d) CNL5; (e) HRTEM images and (f) SAED pattern of CNL5.
XPS spectra of g-C3N4 and CNL5: (a) C 1s and (b) N 1s; (c) UV–vis DRS and (d) Plot of (αhν)1/2 vs hν of the as-synthesized catalysts.

The structures and ELF image of (100) surface of (a) (d) LaFeO3 (100) and (b) (e) g-C3N4 monolayer, respectively, the structure and charge density difference of g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterojunction are respectively shown in (c) and (f).
Calculated the total density of states (TDOS) and projected density of states (PDOS) of (a, c) LaFeO3 (100) surface structure and (b, d) g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterostructure, respectively.

Photocatalytic performance comparison and photoelectric characterization. (a) Comparison of photoreduction of U(VI) over various catalysts; (b) Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS), (c) PL spectra, (d) Time-resolved PL spectra of the as-synthesized catalysts.

The photocatalytic performance of CNL5. Effect of various initial U(VI) concentration (a) and various pH (b) on photoreduction of U(VI); (c) Cyclic stability of CNL5 for photocatalytic removal of U(VI); (d) Treatment of U(VI) in deionized water and spiked real seawater, pH = 5 in deionized system, pH = 8.27 in seawater system.

Identification of the oxidation state of uranium and exploration of photoreduction mechanism. (a) U 4f XPS spectra of CNL5 after photocatalytic treatment of U(VI); (b) U L3-edge XANES spectra of the CNL5 after photocatalytic treatment; (c) ESR signals of CNL5 in deionized water for DMPO-·OH and in methanol for DMPO-·O2 − under dark and light; (d) Effects of various scavengers on photoreduction of U(VI) by CNL5.
Schematic of the photoreduction mechanism of U(VI) by g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterojunction.

head.ce:title: Efficient photoreduction strategy for uranium immobilization based on graphite carbon nitride/perovskite oxide heterojunction nanocomposites

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The photoreduction conversion of soluble U(VI) to insoluble U(IV) is an economical strategy for the efficient removal of uranium from radioactive wastewater. A graphite carbon nitride and perovskite oxide heterojunction composite (g-C3N4/LaFeO3) is designed for the photocatalytic reduction of U(VI) under simulated sunlight conditions from aqueous solution, the reduction-immobilization mechanism is interpreted with the aid of spectroscopic evidence. The proposed heterojunction structure exhibits efficient removal ability (460 mg/g) over a wide range of U(VI) concentrations due to the suppressed recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and the prolonged lifetimes of the photogenerated carriers. The catalytic efficiency is maintained at a high level after five cycles of reuse. The electrons on LaFeO3 transferred to valence band of g-C3N4, U(VI) is reduced by the electrons and ·O2 − on the surface of g-C3N4. The g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterojunction provides a promising strategy for the feasible recovery of U(VI) resources with inexhaustible solar energy.

ce:section.ce:para: The effective treatment of uranium-containing wastewater and recovery of aqueous uranium resources is essential for the sustainable development of nuclear energy [1–4]. Uranium mainly exists in a soluble hexavalent state in aerobic aqueous solution; however, insoluble tetravalent species are dominant under reducing conditions. Therefore, a reduction strategy has been proposed for the efficient immobilization of uranium by constructing a reducing adsorbent and reducing the permeable reactive barrier. Recent work revealed that uranium could be reduced to an insoluble state by photogenerated electrons; therefore, designing and constructing photocatalysts for efficient uranium recovery has drawn the attention of researchers [5–9].

A g-C3N4 semiconductor with an energy gap of 2.7 eV has a terrific response to visible light, enabling the utilization of sunlight for feasibly reducing U(VI). However, the photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4 is limited due to the slow mobility of surface carriers and the fast recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs [10–14]. This defect is effectively improved by constructing heterojunction structures because their binding structure can accelerate the transfer of surface charges, suppress the rapid recombination of electrons and holes, and prolong the lifetime of the carriers [15–19]. A g-C3N4/GO composite was synthesized for the extraction of U(VI) under simulated sunlight, and the maximum extraction amount reached 352 mg/g, while the extraction capacity of pure g-C3N4 was less than 50 mg/g [20]. A g-C3N4/TiO2 heterogeneous composite displayed the ability to simultaneously treat U(VI) and As(III) under simulated sunlight, and its removal rate was twice that of g-C3N4 [21].

Recently, perovskite oxides with the general formula ABO3 (A represents rare earth elements and B represents transition metal elements) have displayed high potential in the fields of sensors, electrode materials, fuel cells, etc [22]. LaFeO3 perovskite oxide exhibits unique photophysical properties; furthermore, Fe can activate peroxide through the redox cycle of Fe3+ and Fe2+ [23,24]. These merits endow the LaFeO3 with high potential as a photocatalyst. The photodegradation efficiency of LaFeO3 for tetracycline hydrochloride reached 92.6 % in 1 h [25]. Cu-substituted LaFeO3 showed excellent photocatalytic activity in the degradation of bisphenol A, with a removal rate up to 92.1 % [26]. Therefore, LaFeO3 is a promising candidate for constructing efficient heterojunction composites to use for U(VI) photoreduction due to the effective electron transfer ability derived from the Fe2+/Fe3+ cycle. However, to the best of our knowledge, no reports have addressed the utilization of graphite carbon nitride/perovskite-type oxide photocatalysts for uranium removal.

By considering the advantages of sunlight utilization and electron transfer, g-C3N4 and LaFeO3 are integrated as a heterojunction composite in the present work for the efficient photoreduction of U(VI) from aqueous solution. The interaction mechanism of g-C3N4 and LaFeO3 is revealed with the aid of density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The photoreduction removal ability for U(VI) is systematically investigated under different water chemistry conditions. The related heterogeneous photoreduction mechanism of U(VI) is discussed by electron spin resonance (ESR) analysis and quenching experiments.

The same amount of dicyandiamide and ammonium chloride were uniformly mixed in 80 mL H2O and stirred for 2 h. The solution was dried in a vacuum chamber until it evaporated to a solid mixture. Subsequently, the mixed powder was calcined in air at 550 °C (5 °C/min) for 2 h. The harvested yellow powder was g-C3N4.

Typically, for g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterojunctions containing 2% LaFeO3, g-C3N4 (2 g), La(NO3)3·6H2O (0.071 g) and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (0.065 g) were dissolved in 100 mL H2O and stirred for 2 h, and the solution was dried with a vacuum freeze dryer. Subsequently, the obtained powder was calcined at 500 °C (5 °C/min) for 2 h, and the obtained sample after cooling to room temperature was a g-C3N4/LaFeO3 (2%) heterojunction, which was denoted as CNL2. Similarly, CNL5, CNL10 and CNL15 containing 5%, 10 % and 15 % LaFeO3 were prepared according to the same procedures mentioned above.

XRD patterns were obtained by a D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, Germany), and the morphology was recorded by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on a Tecnai G2 F30 instrument (FEI, US). The specific surface areas were obtained by a Tristar II 3020 instrument (Micromeritics, US). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted with an AXIS Ultra DLD instrument (Kratos, UK) with an Al Kα radiation source at 10 kV and 5 mA. Room-temperature UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) was performed with a UV-2600 UV–vis spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan). Photoluminescence spectra (PL) were recorded using an FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer (Edinburgh Instrument, UK) at an excitation of 475 nm. Electron spin resonance (ESR) was determined by a Bruker A300 spectrometer (Bruker, Germany), where 5,5-dimethyl-l-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) was used as a probe. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy was conducted at the beamline BL14W1 station of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility. The electrochemical characterization was completed on a three-electrode electrochemical workstation (CHI-660E, Shanghai, China) with a 300 W Xe lamp as the light source. The FTO glass, Pt sheet and the standard Ag/AgCl were used as working electrode, the counter electrode and the reference electrode, respectively. For the working electrode, 20 μL Nafion solution was uniformly coated on the FTO glass, then the ultrasonically dispersed catalyst was covered on the FTO glass.

In a typical photocatalytic process, the as-synthesized catalysts (3 mg) were added to 15 mL 0.1 mM UO2 2+ solutions containing 2 mL methanol (pH = 5). Continuous argon bubbling was applied to ensure that the suspension was in an anaerobic state, and the reaction system was stirred in the dark for 2 h to achieve sorption-desorption equilibrium. Then, the photocatalytic reaction was initiated under simulated sunlight obtained from a 300 W Xe lamp (AM 1.5 G). At given times, 1 mL of suspension was pipetted out and filtered through a 0.22 μm syringe filters, and the concentration of U(VI) in the collected filtrate was analyzed by a UV1800 ultraviolet-visible spectrometer using Arsenazo III at 652 nm. The residual rate (%) was calculated from the initial U(VI) concentration (C0) and at time t (Ct) (Ct/C0 × 100 %).

Spin-polarized DFT simulations were performed with the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [27] using the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) flavor of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [28] and projector-augmented-wave based potential (PAW). Eleven electrons (5s25p65d16s2) for lanthanum (La), eight electrons (3d64s2) for iron (Fe), six electrons (2s22p4) for oxygen (O), four electrons (2s22p2) for carbon (C) and five electrons (2s22p3) for nitrogen (N) were treated as valence electrons. A plane wave basis set with an energy cutoff of 500 eV was used to represent the valence electrons. To avoid interactions between the images of the periodic slabs, a vacuum over 3 nm was considered. Zero-damped DFT-D2 dispersion corrections [29] were used to resolve the problem of poor long-range interaction in the standard DFT calculations. LaFeO3 (100), g-C3N4 and the heterostructure of g-C3N4/LaFeO3 (100) were mechanically relaxed until the total energy was smaller than 1.0 × 10−5 eV and the Hellmann-Feynman force was less than 0.01 eV/Å per atom. Additionally, 7 × 7×1 and 11 × 11 × 1 k-point meshes were applied for the relaxed surface and density of states calculations, respectively [30]. Spin polarization and dipole correction were taken into consideration to meet the convergence criterion due to the intrinsic dipolar nature of these systems. The charge distribution and charge transfer were analyzed by the electron localization function (ELF) and Bader charge approach to deeply understand the interaction between the two surface structures [31,32].

The crystalline phases of the as-synthesized catalysts were studied by XRD, as observed in Fig. 1 a. The distinct characteristic peaks at 13.1 ° and 27.4 ° were attributed to the (100) and (022) planes of g-C3N4, corresponding to the in-plane structural packing motif and interlayer stacking reflection of the aromatic system, respectively; this result indicated that the primary crystalline phase of the composite was g-C3N4. Neither CNL2 nor CNL5 showed clear diffraction peaks of LaFeO3 because of the low LaFeO3 content in the heterojunction composites. As the content of LaFeO3 was increased to 10 %, the diffraction peaks of LaFeO3 emerged on the XRD pattern of g-C3N4/LaFeO3 composite. The TEM morphologies of g-C3N4, LaFeO3 and CNL5 are described in Fig. 1b-d, respectively. g-C3N4 showed a laminar structure with uniform wormholes, which resulted from the introduction of NH4Cl as a dynamic gas template and thermal oxidation etching [33,34]. The pure LaFeO3 demonstrated a uniform sphere with a diameter of approximately 50−60 nm. Regarding CNL5, the LaFeO3 nanoparticles were uniformly dispersed on the g-C3N4 nanosheets to form a heterojunction structure with an intimate interface. Such heterojunction architectures are generally beneficial to the transfer of electrons, mitigating the recombination of electron-hole pairs [35]. The high-resolution TEM image of CNL5 is illustrated in Fig. 1e, and the distinct lattice fringe with an interplanar spacing of 0.2 nm corresponded to the (202) plane of LaFeO3 [36,37]. The concentric circles in the SAED pattern (Fig. 1f) indicated the polycrystalline nature of the as-prepared composites [38].

XPS analysis was performed to clarify the species and valence changes of the heterojunction formation process. C, N and O were visible in the XPS spectrum of pure g-C3N4, while the emergence of La and Fe peaks in the spectrum of CNL5 confirmed the successful introduction of LaFeO3 (Figure S1). The fine C 1s and N 1s spectra of CNL5 are observed in Fig. 2 a and b, respectively. The C 1s peaks located at 284.6, 286.0, 287.8 eV corresponded to sp2 CC, sp3-bonded carbon species, and NCN, respectively [39]. The increased content of sp3-bonded carbon species indicated that CNL5 had more defects, which helped to improve its photocatalytic activity. The N 1s peaks of CNL5 were composed of N=C-N (398.4 eV, sp2-hybridized nitrogen), N-(C)3 (399.7 eV, tertiary nitrogen bonded to carbon), CNH (400.7 eV), and the charge effects in heterocycles (404.0 eV) [40,41]. The optical properties of the catalysts were observed with UV–vis DRS (Fig. 2c). The light absorption range of CNL5 (400−600 nm) was significantly wider than that of g-C3N4. As depicted by the tangent line in Fig. 2d, the band gaps of g-C3N4, CNL2, CNL5 and CNL10 were 2.71, 2.78, 2.67 and 2.73 eV, respectively. The narrowed band gap and widened the light absorption range of CNL5 (2.67 eV) improved the utilization rate of sunlight, thereby promoting the generation of more photogenerated carriers and enhancing the photocatalytic activity [16].

The calculated equilibrium lattice parameters of bulk LaFeO3 (a = 5.562 Å, b = 5.45 Å, c = 7.1279 Å) were comparable with the experimental values (a = 5.5595 Å, b = 5.5509 Å, c = 7.8498 Å) [42] and previous theoretical results [43]. Subsequently, the (100) surface of LaFeO3 was built and relaxed, and the lattice parameters were a = 5.54 Å and b = 5.38 Å (Fig. 3 a). Graphitic carbon nitride networks were constructed to determine the carbon nitride quantum dots of the g-C3N4 monolayer (Fig. 3b). The calculated lattice constants were a = b = 4.79 Å. To gain insight into the bonding nature of the LaFeO3 (100) surfaces and g-C3N4, the electron localization function (EFL) is presented in Fig. 3c and 3d from the top view. The electrons were largely localized around oxygen atoms with a color transition from yellow to red. Based on the Bader charge analysis, 2.901 e and 1.451 e were transferred from the La and Fe atoms to the O atoms. It is well known that with more charge transfers, the ionic bond becomes stronger. From Fig. 3d, a small number of electrons were localized around the [FeO6] octahedron, indicating strong covalent bonding in the Fe-O bonds. With regard to the g-C3N4 monolayer, the transferred charge from C to nearby N atoms was approximately 0.520 e, and each N atom obtained 0.374 e, as depicted in Fig. 3e. The valence charge density distribution and the interaction between the two matrices at their interface played an important role in the catalytic activity. The charge density difference of the g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterojunction was further calculated and is depicted in Fig. 3f; this difference was defined as ⊗q = 〉Tot(r)-〉LaFeO3(100)(r) - 〉g-C3N4(r), where 〉Tot(r), 〉LaFeO3(100)(r) and 〉g-C3N4(r) were the charge distributions of the g-C3N4/LaFeO3 composites, LaFeO3 (100) and g-C3N4 monolayers, respectively. The electrons mainly accumulated on the side of the g-C3N4 monolayer. The Bader topological analysis showed that LaFeO3 (100) acted as the charge donor and that the g-C3N4 monolayer acted as the electron acceptor. As a result, approximately 0.166 e was transferred from LaFeO3 (100) to g-C3N4 in the g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterojunction system, which was consistent with the band structure of g-C3N4 and LaFeO3.

The total density of states (TDOS) and projected density of states (PDOS) of the LaFeO3 (100) surface structure and g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterostructure are depicted in Fig. 4 to further shed light on the electronic properties. Notably, both the LaFeO3 (100) and g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterostructures showed semiconductor properties with band gaps of 2.135 eV and 2.618 eV, respectively. The contribution of the La atoms was mainly from -16.328∼-14.120 eV and 2.104∼6.350 eV with occupations of the 5p (px, py, pz) and 5d (dz2, dx2-y2, dxy, dzx and dyz) orbitals, respectively. In addition, the energy states near -18 eV were mainly dominated by the O-2 s orbitals. The electronic structure slightly upshifted when LaFeO3 (100) and g-C3N4 formed a heterostructure. The interaction of LaFeO3 (100) and g-C3N4 was governed by the hybridization among Fe 3d, O 2p, C 2p and N 2p from -7.5 eV to -2.5 eV, as depicted in Fig. 4d. In this case, the contribution of the La atoms was from -16.062 to -14.080 eV and 2.518–3.550 eV.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Photoreduction of U(VI) by the g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterojunction
ce:section.ce:para: The photocatalytic activity of the as-synthesized catalysts at pH = 5 is illustrated in Fig. 5 a. There was no significant decrease in the U(VI) concentration for a 0.1 mM U(VI) solution without catalyst, indicating that the photolysis of U(VI) was negligible. During the adsorption period in the dark, all catalysts showed weak U(VI) adsorption. Pure LaFeO3 and pure g-C3N4 showed inferior photocatalytic efficiency for U(VI), and the residual uranium in the solution after 40 min of exposure under simulated sunlight was 71 % and 37 %, respectively. The removal ability of g-C3N4 for U(VI) was better than that of the LaFeO3 nanoparticles, which was attributed to the conduction band (CB) of g-C3N4 being more negative than that of LaFeO3 [44]. In contrast, for the g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterojunctions, a rapid decrease in residual uranium was observed in the solution, and the removal rates of U(VI) by CNL2, CNL5, CNL10 and CNL15 were 72.5 %, 93.8 %, 85.0 % and 78.5 %, respectively. The synergistic effect of the heterojunction interface promoted the rapid migration of photogenerated electrons from LaFeO3 to g-C3N4; therefore, the photocatalytic ability was improved compared with that of the individual precursor materials [15]. Additionally, the specific surface area of the catalyst significantly increased from 11 m2/g (g-C3N4) to 70 m2/g (CNL5) (Figure S2), thereby offering more space and active sites for U(VI) reduction and attachment [45]. Note that the removal rate of the as-synthesized samples increased as the LaFeO3 content increased from 2% to 5%; however, the reduction capacity gradually decreased after when LaFeO3 content further increased, the reduction performance of CNL10 was lower than that of CNL 5, and CNL15 was further weakened comparing with CNL10. The introduction of LaFeO3 accelerated electron transfer and increased photocatalytic activity; however, excess LaFeO3 affected the efficiency of electron transfer at the heterojunction interfaces. This result was attributed to i) excess LaFeO3 on the catalyst surface harvesting photons that should be utilized by g-C3N4, thereby limiting the number of photoexcited electrons and ii) excess LaFeO3 becoming a recombination site for electron-hole pairs [37].

Photocurrent measurements and electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) were used to observe the effect of the separation and migration of photogenerated carriers. The photocurrent density further verified the photocatalytic activity trend of composites with different LaFeO3 amounts, namely, CNL5 was better than CNL2 and CNL10. (Figure S3). The photocurrent intensity of CNL5 was significantly stronger than that of CNL10 and CNL2, which clearly implied that CNL5 had a higher transfer efficiency of photogenerated charge [16,21]. Compared with g-C3N4, the smaller semicircular radius of CNL5 (Fig. 5b) suggested that the carriers encountered less resistance during the migration process; thus, the probability of effective action on the target prominently increased [16].

The photoluminescence (PL) spectrum reflected the catalytic activity and represented the separation efficiency of photogenerated charge. The PL spectra of the samples in Fig. 5c displays a strong signal at 475 nm, and the peak intensity of CNL5 was much weaker than that of g-C3N4, indicating that the construction of heterojunctions greatly reduced the recombination probability of photoinduced electron-hole pairs and improved their separation and transport efficiency [46,47]. The time-resolved PL spectra in Fig. 5d further clarified the recombination kinetics of photogenerated electron-hole pairs [34,48]. The lifetime increased greatly from 72.54 ns (g-C3N4) to 108.84 ns (CNL5), although the percentage decreased slightly. Note that when the content of LaFeO3 increased from 2% to 5%, the PL lifetime sharply increased, while the PL lifetime decreased from 5% to 10 % (Figure S4). The PL lifetime of CNL10 was slightly shorter than that of CNL2, but the lifetime ratios of τ2 and τ3 were higher than that of CNL2, which might be the reason that CNL10 performed better than CNL2 (Fig. 5a). Generally, the increased lifetime of charge carriers relies on electron transfer improvements and electronic band structure changes [34,49].

The photocatalytic removal performance of CNL5 under simulated sunlight is displayed in Fig. 6 a. After sunlight irradiation for 40 min, the U(VI) removal rates in 0.1 mM-0.4 mM U(VI) solutions were 93.8 %, 93.0 %, 95.7 %, and 96.7 % (460 mg/g), respectively. CNL5 could effectively remove U(VI) through photocatalysis over a wide range of U(VI) concentrations. Moreover, compared with other recently reported photocatalysts, the CNL5 exhibited considerable photoreduction performance for uranium in relative short equilibrium time (Table S1). The species of U(VI) and the surface properties of the catalyst depended significantly on the pH, which in turn affected the adhesion and removal of U(VI) on the catalyst. Hence, the photocatalytic removal of U(VI) under various pH conditions (4.0–9.0) was investigated in Fig. 6b. Below pH 7, the adsorption and photoreduction of U(VI) increased as the pH increased but decreased as the pH increased above 7. At pH = 7, more than 95 % U(VI) was adsorbed rapidly within 1 h. After 40 min of illumination with simulated sunlight, the residual U(VI) was further removed through photoreduction. However, when the pH was 4, the adsorption and photoreduction of U(VI) on CNL5 was negligible. This result was mainly caused by the surface charge of the catalyst; the surface of the catalyst was positively charged at pH 4 (Figure S5), and U(VI) mainly existed as positively charged UO2 2+; thus, electrostatic repulsion led to weaker adhesion and prevented the further photoreduction of U(VI). As the pH increased, the surface charge of the catalyst gradually became negative, and the electrostatic attraction between UO2 2+ and the surface promoted the photoreduction efficiency of U(VI). As the pH further increased to 8 and 9, the negatively charged (UO2)3(OH)7 − and UO2(OH)3 − species became the dominant U(VI) species, and these species displayed electrostatic repulsion with the negative charge on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, the transmission of electrons was suppressed, which further reduced the adhesion and photoreduction of U(VI) [15,50].

Reusability is a crucial parameter for evaluating the cost-effectiveness and practicality of photocatalysts. The recycling performance of the as-prepared CNL5 was investigated through five successive cycles of photocatalytic reduction removal. From Fig. 6c, no obvious decrease was observed in the photoreduction efficiency of U(VI) after five cycles, which implied the prominent stability and reusability of the as-prepared photocatalyst. Considering actual applications in a real environment, the removal of U(VI) from real seawater that was spiked is shown in Fig. 6d. Under dark conditions, U(VI) was hardly adsorbed by the catalyst in neutral seawater due to the competition between U(VI) and the other ions in seawater. However, under simulated sunlight irradiation, the photocatalyst showed prominent removal efficiency of U(VI) in seawater; this performance was comparable with that in the deionized system. This result suggested that the photoreduction of U(VI) was resistant to the complex components in seawater [51,52].

XPS and XANES investigations were performed to identify the oxidation state of uranium on the catalyst surface after illumination and the interaction between U(VI) and photocatalyst (Fig. 7 a). The U 4f spectra of uranium attached on CNL5 after photoreduction treatment showed two obvious peaks at 380 eV and 381.9 eV, in which the content of tetravalent uranium accounted for 74.6 %. The remaining hexavalent uranium (25.4 %) might be derived from the reoxidation of UO2. From the LIII-edge XANES spectrum of uranium in Fig. 7b, the adsorption edge of CNL5-loaded U(VI) was between the U(VI) and U(IV) standards, indicating that both tetravalent and hexavalent uranium existed simultaneously on the catalyst, which agreed with the conclusion from the XPS results [50,53–55].

To better clarify the reactive species produced in the photocatalytic process, electron spin resonance (ESR) measurements were performed (Fig. 7c). Under dark conditions, no obvious ESR signal was observed. However, the typical characteristics of the DMPO- · O2 − adducts and DMPO- · OH adducts were found under light conditions. This result implied that not only electrons (e−) and holes (h+) affected the removal of U(VI), but · O2 − and · OH also participated in the photocatalytic reduction process [56,57]. Quenching experiments were performed to further clarify the role of various reactive species in the U(VI) removal process (Fig. 7d). The introduction of methanol (hole trapping agent) enhanced U(VI) removal, which was attributed the effective removal of hole (h+), thereby improving the electron-hole separation efficiency. This process was consistent with the conclusion from Fig. 5a. The photoreduction effect of U(VI) became weaker after the introduction of P-BQ ( · O2 − trapping agent), which meant that · O2 − played a positive role in U(VI) removal. Compared with the effect of P-BQ, the addition of TBA ( · OH trapping agent) slightly enhanced the removal of U(VI), the reduction of · OH limited the reoxidation behavior of U(VI). Recent literatures suggested that the introduction of
OH radical trapping agent reduced the recombination rate of photo-generated charges and facilitated the photoreduction reaction [9,53], which fell in right line with our results. When methanol and TBA were introduced simultaneously, the removal effect was better than that of methanol alone. However, when methanol and P-BQ were introduced together, the removal effect was still weak. These results confirmed that · O2 − promoted the removal of U(VI), while · OH oxidized the reduced U(IV) again and decreased the reduction immobilization efficiency of U(VI).

Based on the above discussion, the photoreduction mechanism of U(VI) on CNL5 was proposed and depicted in Fig. 8 . Under simulated sunlight, both g-C3N4 and LaFeO3 were activated to produce electrons and holes (Eq. 1). LaFeO3 acted as an electron donor, while g-C3N4 acted as an electron acceptor. The electrons on LaFeO3 transferred to the valence band of g-C3N4, which inhibited the rapid recombination of electron-hole pairs and allowed more electrons to participate in the photoreaction process. The photoreduction of U(VI) achieved in the CB of g-C3N4 was mainly via Eq. 3. In addition, the photogenerated electrons could produce · O2 − via Eq. 2, and this · O2- also contributed to U(VI) photoreduction, as depicted via Eq. 4. Additionally, the photogenerated holes in the reaction were captured by methanol (Eq. 5).
(1) CNL5 + hν → e − + h +
(2) e− + O2→ · O2-
(3) UO2 2+ + 2e − → UO2(s)
(4) UO2 2+ +2 · O2 − → UO2(s) + 2O2
(5) CH3OH + 6OH− + 6 h + → CO2 + 5H2O

We successfully developed a novel type of graphite carbon nitride/perovskite-type oxide heterojunction for the effective photoreduction of U(VI). The DFT calculation results revealed that the interaction between g-C3N4 and LaFeO3 in the g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterojunction system was caused by the hybridization of Fe 3d, O 2p, C 2p and N 2p from -7.5 eV to -2.5 eV. The PL spectra and time-resolved PL spectra showed that the recombination of photogenerated carriers was effectively suppressed and their lifetimes were significantly prolonged, and the resulting strong reduction ability improved the U(VI) removal efficiency (extraction capacity: 0.4 mM, 460 mg/g). The g-C3N4/LaFeO3 heterojunction exhibited excellent stability and reusability without a decrease in photocatalytic performance after 5 cycles. The photocatalysis experiments under real seawater conditions provided further possibilities for practical application. XPS and XANES analyses were used to identify the species of extracted uranium, which proved the reduction of U(VI). Moreover, the ESR analysis and quenching experiments implied that both e− and · O2 − were beneficial to the photoreduction of U(VI). More importantly, this work not only provides new strategies and insights for the photoreduction of U(VI) but also broadens the horizon for the use of perovskite materials as catalysts.

Shuyang Li: Data collection, writing-original draft preparation. Xiaoyong Yang: Software, theoretical calculation. Zhenpeng Cui: Methodology, writing-review & editing. Yang Xu: Data curation. Zhiwei Niu: Data analysis. Ping Li: Methodology. Duoqiang Pan: Conceptualization, project administration, writing-reviewing and editing. Wangsuo Wu: Supervision.
